title: improved parsing and display of orchestration console
Investigate how application handles multiple open clients
description: given that the application is stateful - how does it handle multiple clients?  does it namespace things like "selected repo?"
notes:
## Multi-Client Investigation Findings

### Architecture Summary
The app is a Next.js application with:
- **Client state**: Zustand store (src/stores/app-store.ts) — in-memory only, no persistence middleware
- **Server state**: Stateless API routes that shell out to the `bd` CLI (src/lib/bd.ts)
- **Data fetching**: TanStack Query with 10s refetchInterval for live polling
- **Persistent storage**: Only localStorage for page-size preference (key: foolery-page-size)

### Stateful Elements Analyzed

1. **Selected Repo (activeRepo)** — Zustand in-memory store
   - Each browser tab/window gets its own Zustand store instance
   - Tabs do NOT share or conflict on activeRepo selection
   - No cross-tab synchronization exists
   - VERDICT: Safe. Each tab is independent.

2. **Filters (status/type/priority)** — Zustand in-memory store
   - Same as activeRepo — per-tab, no cross-tab conflict
   - VERDICT: Safe.

3. **Search query** — URL search params (?q=...)
   - Encoded in URL, not shared across tabs
   - VERDICT: Safe.

4. **View mode, command palette state, row selection, focused row** — Zustand + React state
   - All per-tab, in-memory
   - VERDICT: Safe.

5. **Page size preference** — localStorage (foolery-page-size)
   - Shared across ALL tabs/windows on the same origin
   - If a user changes page size in Tab A, Tab B will pick it up on next read (e.g., after page refresh or re-mount)
   - NOT a conflict issue — this is a benign user preference, and cross-tab sharing is actually desirable
   - VERDICT: Safe. Shared intentionally.

6. **Registry (repo list)** — File on disk (~/.config/foolery/registry.json)
   - Server-side, read from disk on every API call (no caching)
   - Adding/removing repos in one tab is visible to other tabs on next refetch (TanStack Query polling)
   - VERDICT: Safe. File-based, no concurrent write locking needed for this low-frequency operation.

7. **Bead data (CRUD)** — Delegated to `bd` CLI, which operates on .beads/issues.jsonl files
   - All mutations go through the bd CLI which handles its own file locking
   - Server is stateless — no in-process cache of bead data
   - Multiple tabs can update beads concurrently; each sees updates via polling
   - VERDICT: Safe. Stateless server + CLI handles concurrency.

### Cross-Tab Behavior Summary
- **No shared mutable client state** between tabs (Zustand is per-instance)
- **No BroadcastChannel, SharedWorker, or storage event listeners** for cross-tab sync
- **Polling (10s interval)** provides eventual consistency across tabs for server data
- The only shared state (localStorage page-size) is a benign preference

### Potential Improvements (Not Bugs)
- Cross-tab sync of activeRepo selection could be added via localStorage + storage events or BroadcastChannel, but this is a UX preference, not a bug
- TanStack Query's refetchOnWindowFocus (default: true) helps tabs stay fresh when switching between them

### Conclusion
**No multi-client issues found.** The architecture correctly isolates per-tab UI state in Zustand (in-memory only, no persist middleware) and delegates all data mutations to the stateless server/CLI layer. Multiple open clients operate independently without conflicts.

title: Ship Now terminal: stream-json parsing + globalThis session sharing
description: Ship Now terminal spawns Claude CLI but output wasn't visible and no work was done. Three root causes found and fixed in this session.
notes:
# Handoff Capsule — foolery-ez2 (Session 2)

## Context
Ship Now terminal was failing to do actual work. Three issues addressed in this session.

## Fixes applied (all committed & pushed to main)

### Fix 1: `--output-format=stream-json` requires `--verbose` (d194a07)
- **Error**: `Error: When using --print, --output-format=stream-json requires --verbose`
- **Cause**: Claude CLI enforces that stream-json with `-p` also needs `--verbose`
- **Fix**: Added `--verbose` to the spawn args
- **File**: `src/lib/terminal-manager.ts:153`

### Fix 2: Plan mode stall — agent planned but never implemented (72ffcfc → 5e83f1a)
- **Symptom**: Agent entered plan mode, wrote a plan, called ExitPlanMode, process ended without implementing
- **Cause**: In `-p` (print) mode, ExitPlanMode requires user confirmation that can't happen non-interactively
- **First attempt** (72ffcfc): Added prompt instruction "do NOT use plan mode" — user rejected this, wants plan mode because Claude does better work with a self-generated plan
- **Final fix** (5e83f1a): Added `--dangerously-skip-permissions` to CLI args — auto-approves ExitPlanMode and all permission prompts. User has already consented by clicking Ship Now.
- **File**: `src/lib/terminal-manager.ts:151-156`

### Verification
- Commit `1c6bf14` shows a successful Ship Now run landed the foolery-6xc pagination fix, confirming the terminal is now producing real work

## Current CLI args
```ts
const args = [
  "-p", prompt,
  "--verbose",
  "--output-format", "stream-json",
  "--dangerously-skip-permissions",
];
```

## Current prompt
```
Implement the following task. You MUST edit the actual source files to make the change — do not just describe what to do.

ID: <bead.id>
Title: <bead.title>
...
```

## Status
- Ship Now terminal is functional — agents can plan, get auto-approved, and implement
- User reported the latest run still had issues ("no that was never in plan mode") — need more detail on what went wrong in the most recent attempt
- The pagination fix (foolery-6xc) DID land via Ship Now, so the pipeline works at least sometimes

## Key files
- `src/lib/terminal-manager.ts` — session management, process spawn, CLI args, NDJSON parser
- `src/app/api/terminal/[sessionId]/route.ts` — SSE endpoint
- `src/lib/terminal-api.ts` — client EventSource
- `src/components/terminal-panel.tsx` — xterm.js panel

## Related beads
- foolery-083: Bug bead created this session for the stream-json fix (stage:verification)
- foolery-6xc: Pagination bead — successfully shipped by Ship Now terminal

title: Explode feature
description:
You should be able to type in a title and description of a work item on the create/add screen and hit "Hydrate" - which then treats the item as a top level parent of a feature/project/epic.  The llm is prompted to develop the plan for the project as a series of related/hierarchical beads.  this can use the same interface as the "orchestration UI" but with a different name "Hydrate" where instead of "waves", it's just building the bead hierarchy of a top level bead by parsing the plan provided by the LLM into a visualization of unpublished bead metadata.

upon conclusion you can hit LGTM and this triggers the creation of the beads and takes you to the list view, where the top level bead is selected.

title: Foolery Orchestration: Ship Now + Wave Planner
description: Add orchestration capabilities to Foolery: (1) Ship Now - embedded read-only terminal that spawns Claude CLI to execute bead work, (2) Wave Planner - algorithmic grouping of beads into parallel execution waves based on dependencies. Human QA gates represented as gate-type beads blocking wave progression.

title: Ship Now - Embedded Terminal
description: Add an embedded read-only terminal panel (VS Code style, bottom of page) that spawns Claude CLI to execute work on a bead. Uses xterm.js for rendering, SSE for streaming process output, and in-memory session management on the server. Includes a 'Ship' button per bead row.

title: Add xterm.js dependencies
description: Install @xterm/xterm and @xterm/addon-fit via bun add. These provide browser-side terminal emulation and auto-resize.

title: Build terminal-manager server module
description: New file: src/lib/terminal-manager.ts. In-memory session store (Map<sessionId, LiveSession>). createSession(beadId, repoPath?) fetches bead details via showBead(), builds prompt, spawns 'claude -p <prompt> --output-format text' with piped stdio. EventEmitter streams stdout/stderr/exit events. Buffer replay for SSE reconnection. Max 4 concurrent sessions, 5000 event buffer cap, 5min auto-cleanup after exit.

title: Build terminal API routes (SSE + CRUD)
description: Two new route files: (1) src/app/api/terminal/route.ts - POST to create session (accepts beadId, prompt?, _repo?), DELETE to abort session. (2) src/app/api/terminal/[sessionId]/route.ts - GET SSE endpoint using ReadableStream with text/event-stream headers. Replays buffer, subscribes to new events, cleans up on request.signal abort.

title: Build terminal client API + Zustand store
description: (1) New file: src/lib/terminal-api.ts - startSession(), abortSession(), connectToSession() using EventSource for SSE. (2) New file: src/stores/terminal-store.ts - Zustand store tracking panelOpen, panelHeight, activeTerminal (sessionId + beadId + status). Actions: openPanel, closePanel, togglePanel, setActiveTerminal, updateStatus.

title: Build terminal panel component (xterm.js)
description: New file: src/components/terminal-panel.tsx. Fixed-position bottom panel with dark bg (#1a1a1a). Header bar shows TERMINAL label, bead ID badge, title, status, abort/maximize/close buttons. xterm.js loaded via dynamic import() in useEffect. FitAddon for resize. Connects to SSE stream, writes stdout normally, stderr in red, exit with status line.

title: Wire Ship Now button into bead table and page
description: Modifications: (1) bead-columns.tsx - add onShipBead to BeadColumnOpts, add Ship column (Rocket icon) for non-closed/non-gate beads. (2) bead-table.tsx - accept and pass onShipBead prop, add Shift+S hotkey. (3) beads/page.tsx - handleShipBead calls startSession(), sets active terminal, opens panel. (4) layout.tsx - render TerminalPanel after children.

title: Wave Planner - Dependency-Based Execution Waves
description: Algorithmically group open beads into parallel execution waves based on dependency graph. Uses topological sort (Kahn's algorithm) to assign wave levels. Gate-type beads serve as human QA checkpoints between waves. Displayed in a dialog modal with swim-lane visualization.

title: Implement wave computation algorithm (topological sort)
description: New file: src/lib/wave-planner.ts. computeWaves(beads, allDeps) uses modified Kahn's algorithm. Builds DAG from blocks/blockedBy deps (skips parent-child). Assigns wave level = max(predecessor levels) + 1. Groups beads by level, separates gate-type beads as wave guards. Detects circular deps as unschedulable. Sorts beads within wave by priority.

title: Build waves API route + client
description: (1) New file: src/app/api/waves/route.ts - GET ?_repo= endpoint. Fetches all non-closed beads via listBeads(), bulk-fetches deps for each via Promise.allSettled(listDeps()), calls computeWaves(), returns WavePlan JSON. (2) New file: src/lib/wave-api.ts - fetchWavePlan(repo?) client function.

title: Build wave planner dialog UI
description: New file: src/components/wave-planner.tsx. Dialog modal with React Query fetch (enabled when open). WaveRow components: header (wave number, bead count, gate info) + horizontal flex-wrap of WaveBeadCard. Cards show short ID, title, type/status/priority badges, blockedBy. Circular deps section with warning styling. Each card has a Ship rocket button.

title: Wire Orchestrate button into app header
description: Modify src/components/app-header.tsx: Add 'Orchestrate' button (Layers icon) next to Add button in header action area. Manages WavePlanner dialog open state. onShipBead callback closes dialog and triggers ship flow.

title: Wave planner data model v2 (readiness + blockers + diagnostics)
description: Extend wave computation and API payload with readiness semantics and diagnostics that the UI can rely on. Include explicit fields for ready/runnable status, unresolved blockers, and deterministic recommendation ordering.
acceptance_criteria: - API returns enough structured fields for UI without client-side recomputation\n- Recommendation ordering is deterministic\n- Unschedulable/cycle cases are clearly represented

description: Redesign Wave Planner into an actionable orchestration surface inspired by mature workflow UIs (pipeline lanes + execution summary). Include: summary stats, ready-now list, recommended next bead, and one-click Ship Next actions with clear disabled reasons when not runnable.

title: Orchestration UX references and interaction spec
description: Capture UI direction with references to strong open-source workflow UIs and define Foolery-specific interaction patterns (hierarchy, motion, CTA behavior, failure states).
acceptance_criteria: - Notes include concrete references and mapped design decisions\n- Includes interaction spec for ship lock, running state, and errors
notes:
## UX Reference Notes

### References (open source)
- Argo Workflows UI features: https://argo-workflows.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ui-features/
- Apache Airflow UI overview: https://airflow.apache.org/docs/apache-airflow/stable/ui.html
- GitLab issue boards: https://docs.gitlab.com/user/project/issue_board/

### Design decisions for Foolery Orchestration
- Use **pipeline lanes (waves)** as the primary structure, with each lane owning a local "Ship Next In Wave" action.
- Add a **global recommendation rail** ("Recommended Next" + "Ship Next") to reduce decision latency.
- Surface **state at a glance** via top summary cards (runnable, in progress, blocked, cycles).
- Encode readiness directly on cards (Ready / In Progress / Blocked / Verification / Cycle) so users do not infer state from raw status + deps.
- Keep interactions deterministic: recommendation ordering by `wave -> priority -> id`.
- Respect execution safety: one active ship at a time; all other ship actions disabled while running.

### Interaction rules
- Active ship card shows `Shipping...` with red terminate control.
- Non-active cards are disabled while a ship is running.
- Unschedulable items live in a dedicated cycle section.
